conversation.content: Why are you even here? I told you I don't need help with the lighting.
Hey, um, I just thought we could, [cheerful] you know, bounce some ideas around! I've been reading about how color temperature affects mood, and honestly, it's fascinating stuff.
I don't care what you've been reading. This is my project.
Okay, I get that you're protective of your vision, totally understandable. But didn't you mention last week that the client wasn't happy with the first mockup?
That's— well, that's not, I mean, relevant anymore, actually.
Look, I'm not trying to step on your toes here, seriously. Just thought maybe a fresh perspective could help since you seemed stressed about the deadline.
I'm not stressed, okay so, maybe the timeline is, er, tight, but like, I can handle it.
Right, but you've got what, three days left? And you still haven't figured out the accent lighting for the main gallery space, have you?
How do you even know that?
Sarah mentioned it when I ran into her at the supply store yesterday. She said you were having trouble with the track lighting angles creating weird shadows.
Sarah needs to, uhh, mind her own business, the thing is, she doesn't understand my approach.
Your approach of, hmm, using only warm whites? I guess, that could work, but, you know, have you considered how that'll wash out the artwork, basically?
Don't lecture me about color rendering.
I'm not lecturing, just asking questions! You're using 2700K bulbs for contemporary art pieces that need crisp whites, aren't you?
The client specifically asked for a warm, inviting atmosphere.
Sure, but, well, warm doesn't have to mean, sort of, yellow, right? You could, anyway, mix in some 3500K spots for the actual artwork.
I've been doing this for five years. I think I know what works.
Five years of residential work though, right? Gallery lighting is a completely different beast with different requirements for color accuracy and drama.
Are you seriously questioning my qualifications right now?
Not questioning, just pointing out that this is your first gallery installation. Maybe being open to suggestions isn't the worst idea when the client's already expressed concerns?
